title: How do singers make their voice curl when singing? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a line in Beyonce’s “Love on Top” that happens around 1:13 (“c’mon baby it’s you”). She combines falsetto voice with a fast run through several notes. If this is the kind of “curl” you are asking about, then you can consider it a specific technique, and not something that comes naturally. In this passage, Beyonce’s voice takes on the special character that you hear because of three qualities happening together: one, the very high falsetto voice, which has been called “flute-like” because of its being produced at the very top of the vocal range; two, the fast run through a triplet of grace notes; and three, a recording technique in which her voice is doubled briefly to make it pop out on the record.

I’m assuming you’re talking about vibrato or riffs. Vibrato is that sort of waver/tremor in a singer’s voice as they sustain one note. It can be learned or can be natural (if it’s learned badly, you can tell). Riffs are when a singer moves their voice up and down through various notes. Riffs are learned, through lots and lots of practice. I can do vibrato but I’m terrible at riffs, and I’m not good at explaining either, so here’s one of my favorite YouTube videos about it (seriously, it’s super great):  Learn How To Sing / Curls, Vibrato & Riffs Here’s one that takes a camera to the vocal cords of four singers while they’re singing. Kinda cool. I’m not putting the actual video because it grosses me out a little. Vocal Cords up close while singing Also, there are loads of videos of famous singers doing riffs and vibrato, but here’s an actual human being singing vibrato and just a couple short riffs:  Girl sings "Hallelujah" down a well in Italy....Beautiful singing and echo! There are loads of videos on YouTube about learning to sing better. And even very little kids can learn to sing “fancy.” Good luck!
